title: Monday, 5th November 2018

annotations.prefLabel: Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC

bodyHTML:

BE11:11am

Tall brick walls and an advanced security system greet visitors and track their every step. A new, black Range Rover sits in the driveway. Nearby is another of his ventures since leaving Quindell: a 15-acre vineyard for sparkling wine.

His vineyard's website, which features cringe-inducing photographs of Terry with wife Tracey, only lists one wine, available for pre-order at a discount £100. It claims the Quob Park Premiere Cuvée Rose Millésime 2018 has 'a whiff of magnolia blossom followed stridently by perfumed wild-strawberry compote with a hints [sic] of buttered white sourdough toast'.

Badger Have the DM invented a new language- quietcountry- the simple juxtaposition of words creating new ones. Nearly German. so we could have InsightfulFTAlphaville- meaning the power of hope and experience, or perhaps we could go one better...disgracedformerboss - which could be written using only four letters. ('boss' obviously)
BE11:13am

Anyway, click through to Mail story for the full nightmare.

red yet he will still fins backers and it will come to mkt. tis money thats important. but you know this. and thats how you need to be, aware of this, alert to this, when you approach the mkt.

11:19 am

Here's Caz.

BE11:20am

Philippe Lazare’s departure may be a function of the board of directors asserting itself in the face
of bid from Natixis (given his past views, Philippe Lazare would have likely been against any move to sell
Ingenico) and potential for the company to be split into a payment terminals company, which could be sold,
and a payment transactions company, which would then be funded by the proceeds of the sale of the payment
terminals company. Nicholas Huss was previously CEO of Visa Europe and thus knows the payment
transactions business well. Thus, this change in leadership could, in our opinion, mean the company is now more open to a corporate action that splits the low growth but high cash flow terminals business from the high growth payment transactions business that needs funding for future industry consolidation from the terminals business.

A. M. (what it is with sparkling-wine vineyards? first I've come across the nyetimber[sp?] story and now this)
BE11:21am

And Barclays .....

taxloss chateaux verdaflore?
11:20 am
BE11:21am

[W]e have not been fans of Ingenico’s acquisition strategy, but it has bought an interesting collection of assets, albeit at a very high price. We think this collection – Bambora, Global Collect, Easycash, BS Payone – has strategic value, particularly in a rapidly consolidating European market. Its payment assets are growing double digit and we value this at 14-16x EV/EBITDA and terminals at 10x (competitor Verifone traded at 7x prior to take-out at 11x); this would give a €88-95 range. We therefore reiterate our Overweight rating with a price target of €91. This equates to a FY19E EV/EBITDA of 13x and PE of 18x.

VV75 Natixis have clearly stated it will not be a takeover, but rather a merger with thir payments daughter.
tonyb Ingenico: Any speculation on takeover price?
BE11:22am

And UBS.

BE11:22am

While Philippe Lazare made a strong contribution to the success of Ingenico, we believe
action from the board is positive to create shareholder value. Success in the payment
processing side of the business is increasingly important to Ingenico and we are
encouraged to see a new CEO with a strong payment services background (i.e. Nicolas
Huss). We believe that the Retail division (Payment services) is undervalued and new
management could accelerate a rerating.

tadam There is no takeover price because there is unlikely to be a takeover of Ingenico. What is being discussed as far as I understand is a merger with Ingenico remaining a public company.

(Bloomberg) -- Banks are lining up a jumbo leveraged financing of more than GBP3b-equiv. ($3.9b) to back the buyout of RPC Group from Apollo Global Management or Bain Capital, according to people familiar with the matter.

rwl Morning all ! - When is a "holing company" not a holding company? ( cryptic clue : Marr Banks! )

11:28 am

Excel Developer @rwl: I was none the wiser after the interview. so an epic fail by Marr?
BE11:29am

Still. It's an extension. Which is incrementally positive to the prospect of an actual bid arriving in the sense that it's not negative. Want the usual bumf? Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:29am

The fact that Apollo and Bain are still in discussions gives us confidence that the debate around the supposed accounting issues is not a deal breaker. Clearly a bid is not guaranteed but if there was an issue with the numbers, logic suggests that Apollo and Bain would have walked away by now.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

The right price and what the offer might be are not
always going to be the same. Applying the Amcor/Bemis maths for its all-stock August approach and with the Bemis price currently standing at $46.64, Bemis is on a current year PE of 16.7x and an EBITDA multiple of 9.4x. This compares to RPC currently trading on a current year PE of 10.4x and an EBITDA multiple of just 7.0x.

BE11:30am

The outlook. Again a potentially pivotal month for the company, particularly as the interims are due on 28 November. If there is no bid, the bears will take hold while if there is a bid, a minimum of 950p to 1,000p feels to be the tolerance range for shareholders, albeit the market volatility of the past month might see this modestly reduced. It is not the ‘right’ price in our view, hence our 1,230p target price, but one determined by the turbulence over the past 18 months.

The absence of an industry player in the current discussions limits the valuation upside from a transaction, in our view, though we view today's news as incrementally positive for the share price.

Based on Friday’s closing price the shares trade on Apr-19 P/E and EV/EBITDA multiples of 10.4x and 7.3x allowing scope for a bid to be at a meaningful premium to the current share price.

Now I know my Trotskyites well and I know you don’t want to be invested in the U.K. if a Trotskyite is prime minister.”

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Between now and the end of 2021e RBS has the ability to distribute over 90p back to shareholders whilst meeting all regulatory headwinds, including front loading the impact of the final Basel proposals.
This is roughly double the level of distribution potential at other UK banks over the same period. In reality the likely divergence in distributions is likely to be less stark as we expect RBS to run with a buffer for regulatory headwinds, while some other banks will instead absorb such headwinds through ongoing capital generation.
But even if RBS were to fully absorb these regulatory headwinds and other banks chose not to, the distribution potential at RBS is still greater courtesy of its strong starting capital position. Thereafter RBS will benefit substantially having already dealt with these headwinds to capital build and furthermore will not face the sizeable pension contributions that further drag on capital as will likely be the case at Barclays and Lloyds.
We believe next month’s stress test results will highlight the strength of the RBS balance sheet before full year results, where we expect RBS to begin to embark upon returning excess capital back to shareholders over the next few years.

This is likely to impact the timeframe by which STAN is able to make a return commensurate with its cost of capital. After a modest share price recovery following Q3 results and with our own estimates falling, we no longer view the shares as sufficiently cheap in the current environment and downgrade to Neutral.

BE11:51am

October UK new car registrations were -3% YoY, with more important private registrations at -1%. We see limited impact of this release to Pendragon as October represents only c. 5% of annual volume and the timing of re-based guidance suggests management had decent visibility on monthly trading.

Pharma Plus there's the road tax changes earlier in the year, which made it much more expensive to buy a new car, particularly diesels.
Grouchmonkey I see from the SMMT data that Chevrolet sold 2 cars last month. Well done that salesman!
BE11:51am

Detail: Total UK new car registrations in October were -3% YoY, driven by -5% in Fleet registrations which were partially offset by -1% in private and +10% in business. LTM private registrations are running at -7% (7.6% as of September). While WLTP continues to negatively impact sale of diesel (-21.3%), SMMT expects abating regulatory headwinds and easing supply chain issues to limit YoY declines in volume for the remainder of the year. We see limited impact to Pendragon as: 1) October is of low seasonal importance (c. 5-6% of annual volume historically); 2) We believe that the timing of re-based guidance suggests management had decent visibility of October trading.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

And UBS with the pan-European view.

Forester @grouchmonkey I want to call the two Chevy buyers...ripe punters for my mooted boiler room operation!
BE11:52am

According to the respective car associations CCFA, ANFAC, UNRAE and German authority KBA, October sales in the four key European markets decreased by -5.7% y/y (+3.4% ytd). Car sales in France (already reported) declined by -1.5% y/y (adjusted for additional selling day, growth was -5.8%), Spain sales decreased by -6.6% y/y (adjusted for one additional selling day, growth was -11.1%), Italy sales decreased by -7.4% y/y (adjusted for one additional selling day, growth was -11.4%) and Germany sales also decreased by -7.4%y/y (adjusted for two additional selling days, growth was -16%). On a weighted-average basis (for all the four markets), BMW outperformed the markets with +12% y/y, followed by Daimler, whose volumes increased by +9% y/y. PSA volumes decreased by -1%y/y, while FCA performed in line with the market of -6%y/y. Underperformers included VW and Renault, whose volumes declined by -21% y/y, respectively. On a side note, Germany production increased by c3% y/y in October.

Dec69 - Skeptic @ShinShin, with the cut off, most would have been pulling forward towards the cut off as well. When you have a skewed issue and it's not performing in line, is it one to be brave and buy (stock) or short it (obviously sell). For me, I'll stay short as Barclays clearly doesn't buy cars at Inchcape. A quick tally of saleman earnings shows its not great out there.
Sails UK second hand car prices still heading south though surely, even if taxing them went up
BE11:53am

Our view: The October car sales were still partially influence by the WLTP-related bottlenecks and non-availability of some models), which were continued in that month. Comments by OEMs suggest that underlying demand is still strong. However, we note that order intake in Germany was clearly in negative territory, declining 8% y/y. The volumes were also affected by the strong base effect in the same month last year in some parts of Europe (volumes grew in France +14%, Spain +13.7% and Italy +7.1% in October month last year). It is also no surprise that VW is still at the bottom end of the list due to non-availability of some key models. This should improve substantially from here, as VW reconfirmed in the Q3 call. France’s, Spain’s , Italy's and Germany’s combined yearto-date sales growth of +3.4% still compare favourably with our full-year sales growth forecast for Western Europe of +0.8% (we forecast France +2%, Spain +5%, Germany at flat and Italy +5%). UK car sales are expected later today and should provide a full picture of the Top-5 Western European markets. We have a cautious stance on the UK market and expect the car sales to decline by -6% in FY18.
